p.s: The communicative strategy already starts with the title.

The title contains a question that to most would almost seem rhetorical - of course unions are good! which is emidiatelyimmediately contradicted by a simple yes - grabinggrabbing attention, raising curiosity and setting an expectation.
An expectation where the reader prejudges the article to be nonsense, since the expect it to speak against their views.
This is not what happens.
Instead the author tries to smooth into his argument in the lower half by talking about the historic benefits of unions.
The side starts at pro union.
The next paragraph is more emotional and personal.
The author uses personal speech and attempts to signalize that he was once like the reader.
He furthers this emotional connection by using eyecatching keywords in this topic, such as greed, power and moral values.
The side meanders towards the author, who now seems in the middle and very reasonable.
Now the ship has set sail.

The examples he provided earlier were nearly all pro-union - thehe talked about the benefits of unions [...] because workers needed protection from being mistreated by employers and they also needed better working conditions, shorter working days and higher wages [...] (line 2-4).
Unions no longer required [...] [for] good working conditions, good wages, and safe working environment(line 7-9).
The same examples given earlier to paint a good picture of unions are now nullified.
With that positive view gone, the author now has free reign to present his arguments against unions.
The repetition of because creates a simple and clear overview and supports his views, even though no data or objective measurements are presented.
The previously gained legitimacy by pulling the side towards him, is now used to make his point.
This is finalized by the turn-around (don't know the technical term) workers are not being exploited by employers, now employers are being exploited by employees (line 17-18).
Additionally the side is finally pulled to anti-unions by finger pointing them.
unions [...] are one of the major contributors to the economic mess that the world is in today(line 22-23).

This strategy of smoothing into his opinion and slowly convincing the reader and pulling their side from pro-union to the author to anti-union fulfils its purpose through apparent reason and arguments.
